contextId.information: These two clauses have similar meanings, and the "nations" and "peoples" refer to the same group of people. The words "nations" and "peoples" may represent their rulers. AT: "Why are the leaders of the nations in turmoil and making plots that will fail?" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Why are the nations in turmoil ... why do the peoples make plots that will fail?

contextId.information: These two clauses have similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: The kings of the earth take their stand together ... the rulers conspire together

contextId.information: These phrases express very similar ideas.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: the nations for your inheritance ... the farthermost regions of the earth for your possession

contextId.information: These two phrases are very similar in meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: in the morning you hear my cry ... in the morning I will bring my petition to you

contextId.information: These two lines have very similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh has heard my appeal for mercy ... Yahweh has accepted my prayer

contextId.information: These two clauses express similar meanings.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: You make him to rule over the works ... you have put all things under his feet

contextId.information: These two clauses express the same meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: He will judge the world with righteousness ... he will execute judgment for the nations with fairness

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing. Here both "Jacob" and "Israel" represent the people of Israel. The two phrases can be combined in the translation. AT: "then all the people of Israel will rejoice greatly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: then Jacob will rejoice and Israel will be glad

contextId.information: The speaker is saying that it brings him honor to be able to praise God. Both of these clauses express very similar meanings. AT: "Therefore I am glad; I am honored to praise him" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Therefore my heart is glad; my glory is rejoicing

contextId.information: These phrases mean the same thing. Here "your ear" refers to God's willingness to hear someone who prays to him. AT: "pay attention to me ... listen when I speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: turn your ear to me ... listen when I speak

contextId.information: These two clauses have similar meanings. The repetition adds intensity to the writer's words. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Rescue my life from the wicked by your sword ... Rescue me from men by your hand, Yahweh, from men of this world

contextId.information: Both of these clauses have similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: He shot his arrows and scattered his enemies ... lightning bolts dispersed them

contextId.information: These two clauses have similar meanings. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Then the water channels appeared and the bottom of the ocean became visible; you exposed the foundations of the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Then the water channels appeared; the foundations of the world were exposed

contextId.information: Both of these clauses have similar meanings. The writer repeats these ideas for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: For all his righteous decrees ... I have not turned away from them

contextId.information: Both of these clauses have similar meanings. The writer repeats these ideas for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: I have also been innocent ... I have kept myself from sin

contextId.information: Both of these questions mean basically the same thing. The speaker is asking about who is allowed to go and worship Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Who will ascend the mountain ... in his holy place?

contextId.information: Both of these refer to the tabernacle where the writer is worshiping God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: his shelter ... his tent

contextId.information: Both of these phrases mean about the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: like the daylight ... like the day at noon

contextId.information: This same idea is repeated in several different ways to emphasize that Yahweh is dependable and able to give aid. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: helps ... rescues ... saves

contextId.information: These phrases mean basically the same thing and the idea is repeated for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: do not rebuke me in your anger ... do not punish me in your wrath

contextId.information: The first lines of verse 13 and 14 use a simile to present the same image of the deaf man. The writer is so sick that he cannot hear. (See:  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: I am like a deaf man ... hear nothing ... does not hear

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: But my enemies are numerous ... are many

contextId.information: These two phrases have very similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Do not abandon me ... do not stay far away from me

contextId.information: These phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: the end of my life ... the extent of my days

contextId.information: These phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: I am silent ... cannot open my mouth

contextId.information: These three phrases mean basically the same thing and show how strongly the writer wants God to respond to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Hear my prayer ... listen to me ... listen to my weeping

contextId.information: These two metaphors mean the same thing. The writer's danger is spoken of as if it was a deadly pit full of mud. This emphasizes the danger. AT: "from being trapped in a horrible pit full of sticky mud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: out of a horrible pit, out of the miry clay

contextId.information: These phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: You are my help ... you come to my rescue

contextId.information: These phrases are parallel emphasizing how intensely the nations around them mock them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: an insult among ... a shaking of the head

contextId.information: These two phrases are parallel. The writer speaks of loyalty to God as if it were following him, and disloyalty as if it were turning away from him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Our heart has not turned back ... have not gone from your way

contextId.information: These two phrases are parallel. AT: "Walk all the way around Mount Zion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Walk around Mount Zion, go round about her

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are used together for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: See, I was born in iniquity ... as soon as my mother conceived me, I was in sin

contextId.information: These two phrases have the same meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Jacob will rejoice and Israel will be glad!

contextId.information: These two phrases are very similar in meaning. The greatness of God's unfailing love and the greatness of his faithfulness are spoken of as if they could be measured in distance. (See:  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For great is your unfailing love, reaching to the heavens ... your faithfulness to the clouds

contextId.information: This is the same idea expressed in two different ways. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: The wicked go astray even when they are in the womb ... they go astray from birth

contextId.information: In both of these phrases, the wicked people are spoken of as if they were lions, and making them powerless to kill people is spoken of as breaking their teeth. AT: "Take away their power to kill. Make them powerless like young lions whose teeth have been broken and fallen out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Break their teeth ... break out the great teeth of the young lions

contextId.information: These two clauses have similar meanings. The idea is repeated for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: You will prolong ... many generations

contextId.information: These two clauses have the same meaning. The ideas are repeated to emphasize how much the writer thinks about God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: when I think about you on my bed ... in the night hours

contextId.information: These two clauses have similar meanings. The second clause provides more detail by describing what the "secret plotting" sounds like. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Hide me from the secret plotting ... commotion of the doers of iniquity

contextId.information: These two clauses have similar meanings. The idea is repeated to emphasize the importance of praising God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Give blessing to God ... let the sound of his praise be heard

contextId.information: The second clause intensifies the meaning of the first to emphasize the importance of praising God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Let the peoples praise you ... let all the peoples praise you

contextId.information: The second clause intensifies the meaning of the first to emphasize how important it is to praise God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Let the peoples praise you ... let all the peoples praise you

contextId.information: These two phrases refer to the same event. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: when you went out ... when you marched through

contextId.information: This idiom here refers to God's appearance before the Israelites. AT: "when God appeared to the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: in the presence of God

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize the writer's desire to have God protect his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: those who wait for you be put to shame ... those who seek you be brought to dishonor

contextId.information: Here the phrase "you rescue me" explains how God is his "help." AT: "you help me by rescuing me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: you are my help and you rescue me

contextId.information: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Do not throw me away ... do not abandon me

contextId.information: These two phrases have similar meanings and are used together for emphasis. AT: "Yahweh sows light for those who do right, and he sows gladness for those with honest hearts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: Light is sown for ... and gladness for

contextId.information: These two phrases have the same idea and are used together to emphasize how David will not tolerate deceitful people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Deceitful people will not ... liars will not

contextId.information: These two phrases are parallel and emphasize that God does not punish us as we deserve. AT: "He does not repay us with the punishment we deserve for our sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: He does not deal with us ... or repay us

contextId.information: These two phrases share similar meanings and are used together for emphasis. The word "word" refers to the covenant. AT: "He keeps in mind his covenant forever, the promise he made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He keeps in mind ... the word that he commanded

contextId.information: Both of these phrases "the covenant" and "the oath" refer to the same promise that Yahweh made to his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: the covenant that he made with Abraham ... his oath to Isaac

contextId.information: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. AT: "Moses and Aaron performed God's miracles in Egypt among the descendants of Ham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: They performed his signs ... his wonders in the land of Ham

contextId.information: These two phrase have basically the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. AT: "The insects ate all the plants and all the crops in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: The locusts ate up all of the vegetation ... They ate up all the crops of the ground

contextId.information: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together to emphasize that God's people were joyful when he led them out of Egypt. The people were shouting joyfully. AT: "He led his chosen people out with shouts of joy and triumph" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: He led his people out ... his chosen with shouts of triumph

contextId.information: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. AT: "and that he would make their descendants live in foreign lands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: scatter their descendants ... in foreign lands

contextId.information: These two phrases have similar meanings. They compare the greatness of Yahweh's covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness to the greatness of how high the heavens are above the earth. AT: "your covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness are greater than the distance between heaven and earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For your covenant faithfulness is great ... your trustworthiness reaches to the skies

contextId.information: These two phrases are parallel and the phrases "a wicked man" and "an accuser" refer to the same person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Appoint a wicked man ... appoint an accuser

contextId.information: These two phrase have them same meaning and are used together for emphasize how greatly he wishes for them to be ashamed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: May my adversaries be clothed ... may they wear

contextId.information: These two phrases are parallel. The writer speaks of Yahweh helping and honoring people who are poor as if Yahweh caused them to stand up from sitting in dirt and ashes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He raises up the poor ... from the ash heap

contextId.information: These phrases all have similar meanings. The repetition strengthens the ideas. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will protect you ... he will protect your life ... Yahweh will protect you

contextId.information: These three phrases have similar meanings. The third phrase, about the Israelites, is being compared to how the servants and maids look to their masters and mistresses for help. In each case "eyes" refers to the whole person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: as the eyes of servants ... as the eyes of a maid ... so our eyes look

contextId.information: These phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: swept us away ... overwhelmed us ... drowned us

contextId.information: These two verses parallel each other. The second sentence has the same meaning as first sentence, but it gives more details. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Those who sow in tears ... He who goes out weeping ... bringing his sheaves with him
